Package org.jtrim2.property

Class PropertyFactory

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.property.PropertyFactory
public final class PropertyFactory extends Object
Defines static factory methods for creating properties or propery sources.

Thread safety

Methods of this class might be called concurrently from any thread.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are are synchronization transparent and might be called from any context.

  • Method Details

    • memProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memProperty(ValueType initialValue)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field and does not allow null values. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the newly set value of the property is actually different from the actual value.

      This method call is equivalent to calling memProperty(initialValue, false).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified initial value is null
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • memProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memProperty(ValueType initialValue, boolean allowNulls)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the newly set value of the property is actually different from the actual value.

      This method call is equivalent to calling the other two arguments memProperty method with the appropriate PropertyVerifier.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This value may only be null if and only if, the allowNulls argument is true.
      allowNulls - if true then null values are permitted for the returned property (i.e., any value is permitted), otherwise attempting to set null value for a property will yield a NullPointerException to be thrown
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the PropertyVerifier or the PropertyPublisher argument is null. May also be thrown if allowNulls is false and the specified initial value is null.
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • memProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memProperty(ValueType initialValue, PropertyVerifier<ValueType> verifier)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the newly set value of the property is actually different from the actual value.

      This method may throw an exception if the specified PropertyVerifier finds the initial value inappropriate.

      This method call is equivalent to calling memProperty(initialValue, verifier, PropertyFactory<ValueType>noOpPublisher()).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This value will be passed to the specified PropertyVerifier and therefore must be a valid value according to this verifier.
      verifier - the PropertyVerifier which might create a defensive copy of the property value before storing in the internal field and may also verify the validity of the value. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the PropertyVerifier or the PropertyPublisher argument is null. May also be thrown if the PropertyVerifier does not allow null values and the specified initial value is null.
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • memProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memProperty(ValueType initialValue, PropertyVerifier<ValueType> verifier, PropertyPublisher<ValueType> publisher)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. The setValue method of the returned MutableProperty will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the newly set value of the property is actually different from the actual value.

      This method may throw an exception if the specified PropertyVerifier finds the initial value inappropriate.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This value will be passed to the specified PropertyVerifier and therefore must be a valid value according to this verifier.
      verifier - the PropertyVerifier which might create a defensive copy of the property value before storing in the internal field and may also verify the validity of the value. This argument cannot be null.
      publisher - the PropertyPublisher which is used to make a defensive copy of the value of the property before returning (if needed). This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the PropertyVerifier or the PropertyPublisher argument is null. May also be thrown if the PropertyVerifier does not allow null values and the specified initial value is null.
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)
      • noOpPublisher()

    • memPropertyConcurrent

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memPropertyConcurrent(ValueType initialValue, TaskExecutor eventExecutor)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which allows concurrent writes, stores the current value of the property in an internal field and does not allow null values. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners on the specified executor. Note that this property might merge multiple change notifications into a single notifications. This prevents the possibility that many listener notifications might get queued due to many writes. This property does not check if a newly set property is the same as the current one or not. It considers every writes to the property as a change.

      This method call is equivalent to calling memPropertyConcurrent(initialValue, false, TaskExecutor).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      eventExecutor - the executor on which event notification requests are served. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified initial value or the specified executor is null
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • memPropertyConcurrent

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memPropertyConcurrent(ValueType initialValue, boolean allowNulls, TaskExecutor eventExecutor)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which allows concurrent writes and stores the current value of the property in an internal field. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners on the specified executor. Note that this property might merge multiple change notifications into a single notifications. This prevents the possibility that many listener notifications might get queued due to many writes. This property does not check if a newly set property is the same as the current one or not. It considers every writes to the property as a change.

      This method call is equivalent to calling the other three arguments memPropertyConcurrent method with the appropriate PropertyVerifier and a no-op PropertyPublisher.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      allowNulls - if true then null values are permitted for the returned property (i.e., any value is permitted), otherwise attempting to set null value for a property will yield a NullPointerException to be thrown
      eventExecutor - the executor on which event notification requests are served. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified initial value or the specified executor is null
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • memPropertyConcurrent

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> memPropertyConcurrent(ValueType initialValue, PropertyVerifier<ValueType> verifier, PropertyPublisher<ValueType> publisher, TaskExecutor eventExecutor)
      Creates a new MutableProperty which allows concurrent writes and stores the current value of the property in an internal field. The MutableProperty.setValue(Object) method of the returns MutableProperty will call listeners on the specified executor. Note that this property might merge multiple change notifications into a single notifications. This prevents the possibility that many listener notifications might get queued due to many writes. This property does not check if a newly set property is the same as the current one or not. It considers every writes to the property as a change.

      This method may throw an exception if the specified PropertyVerifier finds the initial value inappropriate.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialValue - the initial value of the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      verifier - the PropertyVerifier which might create a defensive copy of the property value before storing in the internal field and may also verify the validity of the value. This argument cannot be null.
      publisher - the PropertyPublisher which is used to make a defensive copy of the value of the property before returning (if needed). This argument cannot be null.
      eventExecutor - the executor on which event notification requests are served. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a new MutableProperty which stores the current value of the property in an internal field. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the PropertyVerifier or the PropertyPublisher or the executor argument is null. May also be thrown if the PropertyVerifier does not allow null values and the specified initial value is null.
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(List)
      • notNullVerifier()
      • noOpVerifier()
      • typeCheckerVerifier(Class)

    • proxyProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutablePropertyProxy<ValueType> proxyProperty(MutableProperty<ValueType> initialProperty)
      Returns a MutablePropertyProxy implementation initially backed by the specified MutableProperty. The replaceProperty method of the returned MutablePropertyProxy will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the actual value of the property changes or not.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialProperty - the initial MutableProperty backing the returned MutablePropertyProxy. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a MutablePropertyProxy implementation initially backed by the specified MutableProperty. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified initial property is null

    • constSource

      public static <ValueType> PropertySource<ValueType> constSource(ValueType value)
      Returns a PropertySource which always holds the same value. Listeners registered with the PropertySource will never be notified and will automatically be unregistered.

      Note that every method of the returned PropertySource is synchronization transparent.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      value - the value of the returned property. This argument is allowed to be null. This value is recommended to be immutable because it is returned as is.
      Returns:
      the property always holding the specified value. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • constSource(ValueType, PropertyPublisher)

    • constSource

      public static <ValueType> PropertySource<ValueType> constSource(ValueType value, PropertyPublisher<ValueType> publisher)
      Returns a PropertySource which always holds the same value. The returned PropertySource will always use the specified PropertyPublisher to share its value. Listeners registered with the PropertySource will never be notified and will automatically be unregistered.

      Note that every method of the returned PropertySource is synchronization transparent.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      value - the value of the returned property. This argument is allowed to be null.
      publisher - the PropertyPublisher used to share the value of the returned property (so it may make defensive copy of the value). This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the property always holding the specified value. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified PropertyPublisher is null
      See Also:
      • noOpPublisher()

    • protectedView

      public static <ValueType> PropertySource<ValueType> protectedView(PropertySource<? extends ValueType> source)
      Returns a PropertySource delegating all of its method calls to the specified PropertySource. This can be used to hide other public methods of the specified PropertySource (e.g.: when having a MutableProperty).
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      source - the PropertySource to which the returned PropertySource delegates its method calls to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a PropertySource delegating all of its method calls to the specified PropertySource. This method never returns null.

    • proxySource

      public static <ValueType> PropertySourceProxy<ValueType> proxySource(PropertySource<? extends ValueType> initialSource)
      Returns a PropertySourceProxy implementation initially backed by the specified PropertySource. The replaceSource method of the returned PropertySourceProxy will call listeners synchronously and will call them regardless if the actual value of the property changes or not.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      initialSource - the initial PropertySource backing the returned PropertySourceProxy. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a PropertySourceProxy implementation initially backed by the specified PropertySource. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified initial property is null

    • noOpVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<ValueType> noOpVerifier()
      Returns a PropertyVerifier which does nothing but returns its argument.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be verified
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier which does nothing but returns its argument. This method never returns null.

    • notNullVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<ValueType> notNullVerifier()
      Returns a PropertyVerifier which throws a NullPointerException if the passed argument is null, otherwise it will simply return its argument.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be verified
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier which verifies that its argument is not null. This method never returns null.

    • typeCheckerVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<ValueType> typeCheckerVerifier(Class<ValueType> expectedType)
      Returns a PropertyVerifier which throws an IllegalArgumentException if the passed argument does not implement the specified type, otherwise it will simply return its argument. The returned PropertyVerifier always allows null values.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be verified
      Parameters:
      expectedType - the type which the argument of the PropertyVerifier must implement. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier which verifies that its argument implements the specified type. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified type is null

    • combinedVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<ValueType> combinedVerifier(PropertyVerifier<ValueType> verifier1, PropertyVerifier<ValueType> verifier2)
      Returns a PropertyVerifier calling both specified PropertyVerifier in the order they were specified.

      This is just a convenience method for calling combinedVerifier(List).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be verified
      Parameters:
      verifier1 - the PropertyVerifier to be applied first. This argument cannot be null.
      verifier2 - the PropertyVerifier to be applied second. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier calling each specified PropertyVerifier in the order they were specified for a given argument. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified PropertyVerifier is null
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(PropertyVerifier, PropertyVerifier)

    • combinedVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<ValueType> combinedVerifier(List<? extends PropertyVerifier<ValueType>> verifiers)
      Returns a PropertyVerifier calling each specified PropertyVerifier in the order they were specified for a given argument.

      You may specify an empty list of PropertyVerifier instances, in which case, this method will return a PropertyVerifier doing nothing but returning its argument.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be verified
      Parameters:
      verifiers - the list PropertyVerifier to be applied in the order they need to be applied. This argument cannot be null and cannot contain null elements.
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier calling each specified PropertyVerifier in the order they were specified for a given argument. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified list or any of its element is null.
      See Also:
      • combinedVerifier(PropertyVerifier, PropertyVerifier)

    • listVerifier

      public static <ValueType> PropertyVerifier<List<ValueType>> listVerifier(PropertyVerifier<ValueType> elementVerifier, boolean allowNullList)
      Returns a PropertyVerifier verifying the elements of a list. The returned PropertyVerifier will always return an unmodifiable copy of the list passed to it. Therefore, if the elements of the list are immutable, the list returned by the PropertyVerifier might be safe to share.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the elements of the list to be verified
      Parameters:
      elementVerifier - the PropertyVerifier called for each element of the list passed to the returned PropertyVerifier. This argument cannot be null
      allowNullList - true if the passed list is allowed to be null, false otherwise. If this argument is true and the list to be verified is null then null is returned by the returned PropertyVerifier. If this argument is false and the list to be verified is null then NullPointerException is thrown by the returned PropertyVerifier.
      Returns:
      a PropertyVerifier verifying the elements of a list. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified PropertyVerifier is null

    • noOpPublisher

      public static <ValueType> PropertyPublisher<ValueType> noOpPublisher()
      Returns a PropertyPublisher which does nothing but returns its argument.
      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value to be stored
      Returns:
      a PropertyPublisher which does nothing but returns its argument. This method never returns null.

    • lazilyNotifiedSource

      public static <ValueType> PropertySource<ValueType> lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource<? extends ValueType> wrapped)
      Returns a PropertySource which notifies registered listeners only if the value actually changes according to its equals method. This is implemented so, that each listener will remember the value set before the previous change notification and will only forward a listener notification if the value actually changes. Note that the first change notification (after registering a listener) is always forwarded regardless if there was actually a change.

      Performance consideration: The returned property adds a small overhead to each listener notification event. If you are using a memProperty, you might want to consider using lazilySetProperty instead.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the PropertySource backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the PropertySource backed by the specified property which notifies registered listeners only if the value of the property has actually changed. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty)
      • lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty)

    • lazilyNotifiedSource

      public static <ValueType> PropertySource<ValueType> lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource<? extends ValueType> wrapped, EqualityComparator<? super ValueType> equality)
      Returns a PropertySource which notifies registered listeners only if the value actually changes according to the specified equivalence relation. This is implemented so, that each listener will remember the value set before the previous change notification and will only forward a listener notification if the value actually changes. Note that the first change notification (after registering a listener) is always forwarded regardless if there was actually a change.

      Performance consideration: The returned property adds a small overhead to each listener notification event. If you are using a memProperty, you might want to consider using lazilySetProperty instead.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the PropertySource backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      equality - the equivalence relation determining if two values of the property must be considered the same or not. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the PropertySource backed by the specified property which notifies registered listeners only if the value of the property has actually changed. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty, EqualityComparator)
      • lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty, EqualityComparator)

    • lazilyNotifiedProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty<ValueType> wrapped)
      Returns a MutableProperty which notifies registered listeners only if the value actually changes according to its equals method. This is implemented so, that each listener will remember the value set before the previous change notification and will only forward a listener notification if the value actually changes. Note that the first change notification (after registering a listener) is always forwarded regardless if there was actually a change.

      Performance consideration: The returned property adds a small overhead to each listener notification event. If you are using a memProperty, you might want to consider using lazilySetProperty instead.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the MutableProperty backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the MutableProperty backed by the specified property which notifies registered listeners only if the value of the property has actually changed. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource)
      • lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty)

    • lazilyNotifiedProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty<ValueType> wrapped, EqualityComparator<? super ValueType> equality)
      Returns a MutableProperty which notifies registered listeners only if the value actually changes according to the specified equivalence relation. This is implemented so, that each listener will remember the value set before the previous change notification and will only forward a listener notification if the value actually changes. Note that the first change notification (after registering a listener) is always forwarded regardless if there was actually a change.

      Performance consideration: The returned property adds a small overhead to each listener notification event. If you are using a memProperty, you might want to consider using lazilySetProperty instead.

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the MutableProperty backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      equality - the equivalence relation determining if two values of the property must be considered the same or not. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the MutableProperty backed by the specified property which notifies registered listeners only if the value of the property has actually changed. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource, EqualityComparator)
      • lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty, EqualityComparator)

    • lazilySetProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty<ValueType> wrapped)
      Returns a property which is backed by the specified property but only sets the value of the backing property if the newly set value is different than the currently set value according to its equals method. The reason to use this method is to make change notifications lazy.

      Warning: Using this method is only safe if the value of the property specified in the arguments cannot change concurrently with the setValue method. Also, this implies that the setValue method cannot be called concurrently, even if it were safe anyway.

      This method was explicitly designed to be used with the memProperty method. For example, you may use: lazilySetProperty(memProperty(initialValue)).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the MutableProperty backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the property which only sets the value of the given property if the value actually changes. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty)
      • lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource)

    • lazilySetProperty

      public static <ValueType> MutableProperty<ValueType> lazilySetProperty(MutableProperty<ValueType> wrapped, EqualityComparator<? super ValueType> equality)
      Returns a property which is backed by the specified property but only sets the value of the backing property if the newly set value is different than the currently set value according to the specified equivalence relation. The reason to use this method is to make change notifications lazy.

      Warning: Using this method is only safe if the value of the property specified in the arguments cannot change concurrently with the setValue method. Also, this implies that the setValue method cannot be called concurrently, even if it were safe anyway.

      This method was explicitly designed to be used with the memProperty method. For example, you may use: lazilySetProperty(memProperty(initialValue), equivalence).

      Type Parameters:
      ValueType - the type of the value of the property
      Parameters:
      wrapped - the MutableProperty backing the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      equality - the equivalence relation determining if two values of the property must be considered the same or not. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the property which only sets the value of the given property if the value actually changes. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null
      See Also:
      • lazilyNotifiedProperty(MutableProperty, EqualityComparator)
      • lazilyNotifiedSource(PropertySource, EqualityComparator)

    • trimmedString

      public static PropertySource<String> trimmedString(PropertySource<String> wrapped)
      Returns a property which transforms to String value of the specified property by removing white space characters from the beginning and from the end.

      For example, if the backing property has the value " TEST STR ", the returned property will have the value "TEST STR".

      Parameters:
      wrapped - the property backing the returned property. this argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a property which transforms to String value of the specified property by removing white space characters from the beginning and from the end. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null

    • convert

      public static <InputType, OutputType> PropertySource<OutputType> convert(PropertySource<? extends InputType> source, ValueConverter<? super InputType,? extends OutputType> converter)
      Returns a property converting the value of a source property using the specified conversion. The conversion is applied each time the value of the property is requested.
      Type Parameters:
      InputType - the type of the value of the source property
      OutputType - the type of the value of the returned property
      Parameters:
      source - the PropertySource providing the input for the given conversion. This argument cannot be null.
      converter - the conversion converting the value of the source property to the value returned by the returned property. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the property converting the value of a source property using the specified conversion. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null

    • combine

      public static <T, U, R> PropertySource<R> combine(PropertySource<? extends T> src1, PropertySource<? extends U> src2, BiFunction<? super T,? super U,? extends R> valueCombiner)
      Returns a PropertySource combining the value of two other properties. The function combining the values is called every time the value gets requested from the source properties.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the first source property to be combined
      U - the type of the second source property to be combined
      R - the type of the combined value
      Parameters:
      src1 - the first source property. This argument cannot be null.
      src2 - the second source property. This argument cannot be null.
      valueCombiner - the function combining the values of the source properties. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a PropertySource combining the value of the source properties. This method never returns null.

    • propertyOfProperty

      public static <S, N> PropertySource<N> propertyOfProperty(PropertySource<? extends S> rootSrc, Function<? super S,? extends PropertySource<? extends N>> nestedPropertyGetter)
      Returns a property viewing the value of the property of a property. That is, if you have a property whose values also have a property, you can view the value of that nested property directly. For example, consider the following code snippet: 
         class A {
     public final PropertySource<B> nested;
   }

   PropertySource<A> root = ...;
   PropertySource<B> directView = propertyOfProperty(root, a -> a.nested);
      In the above code snippet, regardless if the value of root or the value of the current root.getValue().nested changes, directView will detect those changes (providing the current value and notifying listeners properly).
      Type Parameters:
      S - the value of the root property
      N - the value of the viewed nested property
      Parameters:
      rootSrc - the root property whose values contain the property to be viewed. This argument cannot be null.
      nestedPropertyGetter - the function getting the nested property from the values of rootSrc. This argument cannot be null and the function may not return null.
      Returns:
      a property viewing the value of the property of the given root property. This method never returns null.
